Dietary analysis is often comprised of two parts, needs and intake.
Optimal nutrition is often referred to as a matter of energy balance (energy-in versus energy-out) however there are many variables that need to be considered.
The body does not simply operate on a mathematical equation as there are many factors that need to be taken into consideration in the total preparation of ones diet.
Metabolic rate - The term metabolic rate can be divided into three components:
Basal metabolic rate (BMR)- is the amount of kilojoules burned at rest and contributes 50-80 per cent of your energy used.

Energy used during physical activity- this is the amount of kilojoules or calorie burned during movement and physical activity; in a normally active person, this component contributes 20 per cent of daily energy use.
Thermic effect of food - this is the energy you use to eat, digest and metabolise food. It contributes about 5-10 per cent of your energy use.
BASAL METABOLIC RATE OR RESTING ENERGY EXPENDITURE

BMR is the energy required for cellular and tissue processes that maintain physiological functions at rest, Muscular activity contributes slightly on BMR. BMR can also be referred as the energy the body needs to maintain itself in the sedentary state Though every individual has a slightly different BMR, the average of the energy expenditure rate is about 70 calories per hour. Slightly more when we are awake but slightly less when we are sleeping. Many factors such as gender, muscle mass, body temperature and age can affect BMR.

Men usually use more calories than women. The more the lean muscle mass, the higher the BMR is. This is also the reason why we need to build up more muscles because you can burn more calories! BMR decreases with age. More energy will be used to generate heat under low temperature.

BMR however is mainly determined by genetics and general physiological factors. Only proper diets where it includes balanced proportion of fats, carbohydrates and proteins together with age-appropriate exercise will assist in achieving your fitness and weight loss goals.

It can increase a person’s metabolism due to moderate and strenuous physical activity. The exact amount of energy this accounts for depends on the physiological ‘’cost’’ of the activity. For example, when we move, we need energy for muscle movement. And that creates the ‘’cost’’ of activity. How fast we move is one of the factors on how much energy we spend. The faster you move, the more energy you use given in the same amount of exercise time. For example, running takes more energy than pilates class under the same time output.
Practical strategy : Small and frequent meal,
Due to the thermic effect of food, after ingesting any food, it uses energy for digestion, absorption and metabolize the food.
This means, the more the TIMES you eat, the more the energy you will consume.
Also, skipping meals will just make you eat more in the next meals.
If you overload your body with food, where your body cannot use the energy in time, it will be converted to fat for storage.

It is the energy used due to the cost of processing food for storage and use In other words, it is the energy expended by our bodies to process food. It usually referred to digestion, absorption and metabolism of food. Different marconutrients require different energy levels for process and as such can be more predisposed to be stored as fat. Discussion: you may probably hear of high protein diet for weight loss purpose. Why do you think high protein meals help to lose more energy? Try to answer that at the end of this part. The term ‘’thermic effect of food’’ is used to describe the energy expended by our bodies in order to consume (by biting, chewing and swallowing) and process (from digestion, transportation, metabolism and storage) food. We ‘’expend energy’’ by burning calories. Processing protein requires the most energy among the three macronutrients. It is estimated to be as high as 30% of the calories consumed. Dietary fat on the other hand requires the least energy. It is more easily processed and converted to body fat. The thermic effect can be as little as 2-3%. The energy for processing carbohydrates is in between that of the protein and fat. It is about 5-10%

Your BMR is increased after eating because you use energy for digesting, metabolizing and absorbing the food. This rise occurs once you start eating and reaches the peaks after 2 to 3 hours upon eating.

As mentioned before, different macronutrients contributes different percentage the energy use due to the thermic effect of food. Here is the reference: Fat: raises BMR around 3%. Carbohydrates: raises BMR about 8%. And protein raises BMR up to 30%.

(*Answer to the question: When you consume the same amount of protein, carbohydrate and fat, protein takes the most energy for metabolizing, following by carbohydrate and then fat. It is because it takes more energy to metabolize amino acids into fat then to convert glucose into glycogen or transfer absorbed fat into adipose store. That is to say, protein has the highest thermic effect of food while fat has the lowest.)(*Answer to the question: When you consume the same amount of protein, carbohydrate and fat, protein takes the most energy for metabolizing, following by carbohydrate and then fat. It is because it takes more energy to metabolize amino acids into fat then to convert glucose into glycogen or transfer absorbed fat into adipose store. That is to say, protein has the highest thermic effect of food while fat has the lowest.)

As you can see, all calories are not equal. If you eat an equal number of calories of protein, fat and carbohydrates, the calories in the fat are more likely to end up on your waist as fewer of them are burned off by the thermic effect. A figure of 10% is generally used to account for the thermic effect of food. This means that if you want to replace 500 calories burned through activity, you need to eat 10% more, or 550 calories. And if you eat 500 calories, 10% of them will be burned off by the thermic effect, leaving only 450.
When designing a diet or advising regarding a person dietary habits there are a host of factors that must be taken into consideration to promote success. Some things to consider are:

Food likes and dislikes, Occupation, Cultural differences, Vegetarian, Vegan, Emotional connections to food, Time availability, Knowledge of food choices, Food allergies, Financial constraints, Level of commitment / dedication
THE NEED FOR DIETARY ANALYSIS FOR ATHLETES

Lack of fibrous carbohydrates (vegetables), sometimes none at all, Over-consumption of junk food, Severe energy deficits, especially from endurance athletes, young athletes just moved out from home, excessively thin female athletes, Poor Iron, Calcium, Zinc, B vitamins, and nitrogen levels in vegetarian athletes Approximately 80-90% of the general population have inappropriate zinc intake (ACSM 2000) and 10% of female athletes have iron deficiencies. Insufficient consumption of protein intakes by lazy athletes and not enough essential fatty acids in their diet (EFA’s). Many athletes forget to eat breakfast and/or skip lunch.

Remembering the personal trainer is simply writing a suggested diet for healthy individuals. As a fitness trainer, if you encounter medical conditions which require specific dietary intake, Then you must realise that there are limitations in you providing this type of nutritional information, Therefore you should be aware of allied health professionals who can assist or, alternatively, you may be able to recommend one.

Carbohydrates belong to a class of substances called macronutrients, meaning nutrients that the body needs in large amounts Carbohydrates are an important macro nutrient for the body as they are the main providers of energy to drive metabolic reactions Carbohydrates are also the preferred fuel source for brain function

The main elements that make up Carbohydrates are Carbon, Hydrogen, and Oxygen (C-H-O) Most carbohydrates have a ratio of 1:2:1 of carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen, respectively Carbohydrates can be classified in three main groups
These are single molecules of sugar. The monosaccharide's are:

Glucose - is found in most carbohydrate foods including sugars and starches. They are the building blocks of carbohydrate. Glucose is the main energy supplying molecule for the body Fructose - is also known as fruit sugar and thus is found in fruits. It is converted into glucose by the liver, and Galactose- is part of lactose, the sugar found in milk.
These are two linked sugar molecules which are broken down into the monosaccharide's by digestion. The disaccharides are:
Sucrose = glucose + fructose Lactose = glucose + galactose Maltose = glucose + glucose
Sucrose (table sugar) normally comes from sugar cane. Lactose is found in milk and milk products. Maltose is formed when starch is broken down.

Starch is simply hundreds of molecules of glucose sugar joined together. When starch is digested, it is first broken down into maltose and then into glucose. There are generally two (2) types of carbohydrates often referred to in dietary recommendations; that is; starchy and fibrous carbohydrates. Starchy carbohydrates broadly fall into things like breads, pasta, rice and cereals. Fibrous Carbohydrates are generally predominantly anything green, e.g.: vegetables salads.
GLYCEMIC INDEX (GI) What is the glycemic index?
A scale that ranks carbohydrates by how much they raise blood glucose levels compared to a reference food
25 or 50 grams carbohydrate of test food. Blood samples taken: 1st hour: every 15 minutes 2nd hour: every 30 minutes 3rd hour: every 30 minutes*
Values plotted; AUC calculated. Test food response compared to reference food response. Average GI of 8-10 volunteers = GI of test food
Absorbs less water Molecules form tight clumps Slower rate of digestion
Absorbs more water Molecules are more open Faster rate of digestion

Glycemic load measures the degree of glycemic response and insulin demand produced by a specific amount of a specific food. Glycemic load reflects both the quality and the quantity of dietary carbohydrates.

The glycemic load is a relatively new way to assess the impact of carbohydrate consumption but gives a fuller picture as opposed to the glycemic index alone, GL simply tells you how much carbohydrate there actually is found in a carbohydrate food. A GI value tells you only how rapidly a particular carbohydrate turns into sugar. You need to know both things to understand a food's effect on blood sugar.

Watermelon has a high GI, but compared to other foods you might eat, it doesn’t have as much carbohydrate because it is mainly water. The small amount of carbohydrate in watermelon is absorbed very quickly making it a high-GI food, but because there is so little it won’t have much effect on your blood glucose levels, so in terms of impact, it is very low. This is termed ‘glycemic Load’. A good web page to find out Glycemic index and Glycemic loads of many popular Australian foods is… www.glycemicindex.com

The GI in particular has grown tremendously in popularity of late and does offer some benefits in selecting healthy carbohydrate sources. Consequently it also has some limitations associated with it and as such many food manufacturers have exploited this fact to the unsuspecting buyer.

Carbohydrates are measured in a fasted state so only really applies to breakfast (Break – Fast), Combining carbohydrates with other macro nutrients (fats, protein) can change the GI rating significantly, Carbohydrates generally (there are exceptions) aren’t eaten by themselves thus won’t have a true score based on the GI rating, GI does not demonstrate the total carbohydrate content
FOOD LABELLING BASED ON GI ENDORSEMENT OR LISTING

When making suitable food choices many people will look at products that have listed on their labelling a low GI for example. With these food choices the real key is to look at the ingredient list as this is something that has to be listed correctly by legislation and gives you the true picture of what you are eating. The ingredient list is always listed from the most to the least. There are many products that claim to have a low GI but list sugar as their first (most) ingredient in the total product.
SUGAR HAS THE HIGHEST GI RATING?

To do this they simply combine fats with the sugar which slows its absorption rate thus changing the GI factor. It is well known and recommended by the GI advocates to avoid or minimise sugar content as much as possible in any foods consumed.
“I was told to eat lots of fruit to lose weight… is this true?”

Fruit does have some great benefits including it tastes great! It is a good source of vitamins and minerals and is easily available to everyone, i.e.; when you are on the road, travelling etc. Ok but how does it relate to the person trying to lose some FAT. First you may have heard of fructose which is fruit sugar.
SUGAR HAS THE HIGHEST GI RATING?

Fructose is primary used by the liver in two ways, used as energy (converted to glycogen) or into triglycerides (fat). To convert it to energy, which is the best situation we want, it is achieved through an enzymatic process via the liver. However there can be a problem if we consume too much fruit in one day as the liver has limited fructose-converting enzyme. Most people on average can only convert about 50 grams (200 calories) of fructose to glycogen per day then the rest is converted to FAT.

Fats are organic compounds that are made up of carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen; they are the most concentrated source of energy in foods. Fats belong to a group of substances called lipids. Fats come in liquid or solid form. They provide nine calories per gram, more than twice the number provided by carbohydrates or protein. Eating too much saturated fat in particular is one of the major risk factors for heart disease.
Fats that help to lower blood cholesterol if used in place of saturated fats Most (but not all) liquid vegetable oils are unsaturated.

Fats that help to lower blood cholesterol if used in place of saturated fats. However, mono-unsaturated fats have a lot of calories, so you still need to limit them. Examples include olive and canola oils.

Fats that help to lower blood cholesterol if used in place of saturated fats. However, polyunsaturated fats have a lot of calories, so you still need to limit them. Examples include safflower, sunflower, corn, and soybean oils.

These fats form when vegetable oil hardens (a process called hydrogenation). They can lower HDL levels ("good cholesterol"). These are found in fried foods, commercial baked goods, processed foods, and margarines. These should be avoided as much as possible as they are linked to heart disease.

Refers to oils that have become hardened (such as hard butter and margarine). Foods made with hydrogenated oils should be avoided because they contain high levels of trans fatty acids. The terms "hydrogenated" and "saturated" are related; an oil becomes saturated when hydrogen is added (i.e., becomes hydrogenated).
Refers to oils that have become partially hardened. Foods made with partially hydrogenated oils should also be avoided because they contain high levels of trans fatty acids.

These are the biggest dietary cause of high LDL levels ("bad cholesterol"). Saturated fats are found in animal products such as butter, cheese, whole milk, ice cream, cream, and fatty meats. They are also found in some vegetable oils. These should also be avoided as much as possible.

The "good" fat – also known as Essential Fatty Acids (EFA’s). There are two families of EFA’s, Omega-3 (linolenic acid) and Omega-6 (linoleic acid). Omega-3 and Omega-6 EFA’s are the raw materials used to make all the special fats in the structure of your brain, eyes, ears, testes, ovaries, adrenals and the membranes that surround and protect every cell in your body. You must get EFA’s from your diet, because your body cannot make them. Omega-3 EFA’s are found in the body oils of cold-water ocean fish like cod, mackerel, tuna and also found in vegetable oils like Macadamia nut. The healing and preventive abilities of Omega-3 in fish oil have been documented in countless studies in the U.S. and Europe.

The most significant benefits of Omega-6 include ensuring fat regulation and energy distribution (which aids in weight-loss), and reducing the intensity of PMS symptoms. High concentrations of Omega-6 are found in safflower oil and Macadamia nut oil. In addition, Omega-6 assists Omega-3 in reducing all kinds of inflammation, lowering LDL cholesterol and promotes optimal immune function.

Burn fat: Helps the body eliminate excess fat. Prevent heart disease: Dramatically reduces the risk of heart disease by providing a slippery protective coat on the walls of the arteries, thus inhibiting plaque from sticking to arterial walls. Relieve Arthritis pain and inflammation: Extremely effective in relieving the symptoms of arthritic conditions by suppressing inflammation. Fight cancerous growths: Helps prevent cancer from growing by blocking cells that nourish the cancer. Reduce symptoms of PMS and Menopause: Help relieve the drying of vaginal and bladder tissues in menopausal women, which helps ward off urinary tract infections.
The following are just some of the ways that the two families of EFA’s, Omega-3 and Omega-6 can benefit you:

The word protein comes from the Greek word ‘proteios’ which means of great or primary importance. Proteins are organic compounds made up of carbon, hydrogen, oxygen and nitrogen. It is the presence of the nitrogen which sets protein apart from other nutrients. Since we have no other source of nitrogen one of the most important roles of protein is to bring nitrogen into the body. Protein is thus broken down into amino acids within the body.
Protein requirements of athletes are increased well above those of sedentary people, Due in part to changes in amino acid metabolism induced by intense
ROLE OF PROTEIN / AMINO ACIDS ARE…
Recovery, assisting immune suppression Build proteins of new tissue Support new growth and maintenance of cells, and making of working parts of cells Facilitate chemical reactions
Provide energy Growth & maintenance Hormone production Transportation i.e. Haemoglobin Blood clotting Structural components

Contrary to what many dieticians believe, the RDA (Recommended daily allowance) was never meant to provide protein requirements for active individuals. Additionally, numerous studies have shown that exercise increases the need for protein (1,2). It’s important to understand that protein requirements most definitely increase in athletes. Data reviewed by Dr. Peter Lemon indicates that endurance athletes may need 1.2-1.4 g/kg of protein and strength athletes 1.6-1.8 g/kg to maintain a positive nitrogen balance (meaning that protein is being stored in the body) (3).

Dr. Peter Lemon also found that endurance athletes need 25-50 percentmore protein than the RDA, Dependent upon the intensity and duration of the activity. A study reported in The Physician and Sports Medicine showed that weight trainers (those who spend lots of time in the gym) need protein at a rate of 438 percent higher than the RDA. To keep them in a positive nitrogen balance, equating to about two to two and half grams per kilo of body weight.

A small study at the University of Illinois found that a protein-rich diet boosted the effects of exercise in women trying to lose weight, In the four-month study, a group that substituted high-quality proteins for foods high in carbohydrates lost more fat (including more abdominal fat) than a group that consumed the same number of calories but more carbohydrates, A "high-exercise" portion of that group lost even more weight, and almost 100 percent of it was fat. In the high-carbohydrate, high-exercise group, as much as 25 to 30 percent of weight lost was muscle.

Elite Australian male athletes are known to have a daily protein intake over 1.5g/kg (Burke et al. 1991) In healthy male athletes who consumed long term daily protein intake of up to 2.8 g protein/kg body weight, no negative effects on renal function were found (Poortmans & Dellalieux 2000). There is no published evidence that a diet containing up to 2.8 g protein/kg/day produces adverse effects on kidney metabolism in athletes. In addition, no known association of protein intake with progressive renal insufficiency has been determined (Brandle et al. 1996).” (NH&MRC 2005 p 259).

Many health professionals imply that protein supplementation is unnecessary and that the recommended daily intake for protein is easily achieved via normal dietary intake. However, this argument is based on the assumption that everyone consumes a well balanced diet containing a range of high quality protein sources. In today's hectic world how many people actually achieve this? If you don't achieve your recommended daily intake of protein each and every day a protein supplement MAY definitely be of benefit. A good guideline to follow in terms of nutrients on a plate is this formula: 1/3 Protein to 2/3’s good nutrient rich complex/fibrous carbohydrates.

The chosen athletic endeavourer, i.e. a distance runner’s pre-event meal would be more unique compared to a, weight resistance workout meal. Duration of workout or competition, Bodyweight and environmental conditions, Timings of meal ingestion. i.e. a meal consumed 20 minutes pre- event would be somewhat different that a meal consumed three hours prior. Length of workout / competition. i.e. energy expenditure would be higher for a 90 minute session compared to a 30 minute session; hence meal size and macro nutrient ratios would alter accordingly, and Timings of workouts. i.e. training first thing in the morning compared to later in the day.
To determine an appropriate meal selection in particular the pre-event / workout meals, there are many factors that should be taken into consideration such as…

It is generally accepted and often recommended that the pre-event meal predominately contains a suitable source of carbohydrates whilst maintaining a low fat content. However remembering this is coherent on the previously mentioned considerations. The pre-event meal has different goals than the post workout meal, The goal of the pre-event meal is to provide all the necessary specific nutrients for energy production to allow the athlete to perform effectively, It has now being scientifically verified that consuming a portion of protein combined with a carbohydrate source preferably in liquid form for digestibility issues before a workout reduces the possibility of muscle wastage.

The idealistic timing for this method would be for example a weight training session being performed first thing in the morning were the trainee would consume a small portion of protein and carbohydrates approximately 20 - 40 minutes prior to commencement. Without adequate supplies of the necessary nutrients the body can and will use other substrates for energy production (muscle loss). This obviously will in turn affect performance outcomes. This is not suited to every athletic endeavour as the specifity principle must apply however it pertains to the vast majority.

The goal of this meal is to effectuate efficient recovery from training or competition. The timings of this meal are of paramount importance as delayed ingestion of nutrients causes a chain of negative effects within the body which hampers recovery substantially. The body has, which is often referred to as, a window of opportunity post training which allows a higher uptake of nutrients to assist in things such as glycogen/ATP replaced thus maximising recovery. This window in relation to time is generally accepted to be approximately three hours however this is dependant on the timing of the first meal post workout.

The main opportunity window appears to be in the first 45 minutes of completing the workout. If a meal is ingested within this time frame then the window will stay open but decrease as time passes. If a meal is not consumed within this time frame then the window of opportunity diminishes quickly and sets of a negative chain of events. Through the process of training intensely the body is able to digest a larger amount of nutrients post workout than any other time. In light of this finding it is recommended that your largest meal should be post workout consisting of a quality carbohydrate and protein source.

However the problem lies within the fact that after training most people have difficulty in eating let alone consuming a large solid meal. The answer therefore often is consuming a liquid source of nutrients immediately finishing training and consuming a solid meal within 90 minutes of completing workout/event. Liquid sources allows quick effective nutrient uptake which is ideal for post workout/event requirements. The post workout meal should consist of a quality carbohydrate and protein source. This may be as suggested in liquid form. Preference is always given to solid meals however post workout is differently an exception.

A fast absorbing protein such as Whey protein isolate and a high glycemic carbohydrate source such as dextrose is an ideal combination. It is scientifically accepted that fast nutrient uptake post workout is important to maximise recovery. Potential supplementation that can be utilised to assist recovery and is commonly found amongst educated elite athletes is:
Glutamine, Branch chain amino acids, Protein powder such as, Whey Protein Isolate (WPI), and Carbohydrate source such as dextrose or maltodextrin
WHY DO WE NEED TO HAVE FOOD LABELS?

Tell us which nutrients, in what amounts, are in a product Warn us if a food contains food allergens Inform us if the food is fresh or out of date Explain how to store, prepare or cook the food we buy List product ingredients Give us information on where the food was produced and by which company
Food labels provide information to help us make healthier and safer food choices. They
Essentially, food labels are there to provide us with basic information about what is in the food we eat and how nest to handle it.

Food labels tell us exactly what we are paying for, so it really does pay to take the time to read them In Australia all packaged and manufactured foods must have a food label and nutrition information panel. By law, they must be accurate and not contain misleading information Nutrition information is available on every food label. It can help us to make healthier and informed food choices, resulting in better health. Understanding how to read a label will help you make sure you are making the best choices for you and your client. Food manufacturers commonly use words, statements or symbols on food packets that can often be confusing and misleading causing consumers to think that a particular product is a healthier choice.

Name of the food Best before or Use by date Ingredients list - listed from greatest to smallest weight Declaration of potential allergens - such as nuts, seafood, milk, eggs and gluten List of food additives - found in the ingredients list Declaration of genetically modified ingredients Storage information Manufacturers name and address Country of origin

Light or Lite: Doesn’t always mean lower in fat or kilojoules. It may mean less salt or even just a “light” texture or taste No cholesterol: This doesn’t necessarily mean low fat. Vegetable foods do not contain cholesterol (only animal foods have cholesterol) but vegetable oils may be high in total and saturated fat. Saturated fat can raise your blood cholesterol levels 97% fat free: The food contains no more than 3% fat or 3g of fat per 100g. These foods are low in fat. However, they may still be high in sugar and kilojoules Reduced fat: This means the food has less fat than the standard product. However these foods are usually NOT low in fat

No added sugars: Sugar is not added to the food, but the food may be naturally high in sugars, which may also make it high in kilojoules Diet or low-joule: These foods usually have artificial sweeteners No added salt or reduced salt: Salt has not been added or the normal quantity has been reduced. Reduced salt foods are not necessarily low salt foods High fibre: The food
WHAT ARE THE COMMON NAMES ON LABELS?
GETTING THE MOST FROM NUTRITION INFORMATION PANELS

Per 100g: Useful standard to compare one brand against another Energy / Kilojoules: The energy value is the total amount of kilojoules from protein, fat, carbohydrate, dietary fibre and alcohol that is released when food is used by the body. Protein: It includes both animal sources such as meat, poultry, fish, eggs, milk and cheese AND plant sources such as lentils, dried peas and beans, nuts and cereals.
GETTING THE MOST FROM NUTRITION INFORMATION PANELS

Fat: Low fat foods have no more than 3 grams of fat per 100g. Foods with higher fat contents can be healthy choices if the saturated fat content is low. Children (especially those under 2 years of age) need some higher fat foods Saturated fats: Look for less than 3g per 100g Carbohydrate: Found in bread, cereals, rice, pasta, milk, vegetables and fruit. It includes both starches and sugars. Starches are found in high amounts in foods such as white, wholemeal and wholegrain varieties of cereal, breads, rice and pasta, together with root vegetables and legumes. Sugars: Most natural, unprocessed foods have sugar contents less than 15 grams per 100g. Naturally occurring sugars e.g.. Those in dairy and fruit are better choices than added sugars
GETTING THE MOST FROM NUTRITION INFORMATION PANELS

Dietary fibre: Pick a product that is higher in fibre (per 100g), especially when comparing cereals, bread, biscuits Sodium: Where possible, choose products with reduced or no added salt. Low salt products have less than 120mg per 100g. Try to always choose products with less than 400mg salt per 100g. Ingredients: Manufacturers must list ingredients in terms of quantity. Thus ingredients listed first will be found in the largest amounts in that food.

Name of the food Best before or Use by date Ingredients list - listed from greatest to smallest weight Declaration of potential allergens - such as nuts, seafood, milk, eggs and gluten List of food additives - found in the ingredients list Declaration of genetically modified ingredients Storage information Manufacturers name and address Country of origin

It is important to remember, when suggesting food choices for your clients, that you are aware of food labelling methods. Many of these methods are employed by the manufacturer to entice the consumer to buy their specific products. Detox advocates believe that certain foods are toxic to the body, particularly refined and acid-forming foods. When our bodies break down these refined sugars, they produce a by-product of acidic deposits (toxins) that accumulate to cause a sluggish digestive system. By ‘detoxing’ it is believed, you eliminate these toxins from your diet, giving the digestive system the chance to function more efficiently, helping you to burn off more calories.
Detox programs health claims of improving:
Bowel health, Revitalizing the skin and liver, Increasing energy levels, and Aiding in weight loss

A standard detox will involve a clean-up of your diet. The revised diet is then based on fruit, vegetables and water, while cutting out meat (optional), alcohol, caffeine and processed foods. On a detox, you should try to eat as much organic and raw food as possible. You are also encouraged to eat plenty of dark green leafy vegetables, brown rice, soups and vegetable juice. Water also plays a prominent role.

As detox programs have not yet been clearly defined, it is impossible to judge whether or not they work. Advocates assert that detox programs encourage healthy eating patterns however critics argue that there is no evidence to support the belief that such detox regimes help remove toxins from the body. They claim that the lungs, kidneys, liver, gastrointestinal tract and immune systems already remove or neutralize toxic substances.

Some people follow a "vegetarian" diet, but there's no single vegetarian eating pattern. The vegan or total vegetarian diet includes only foods from plants: fruits, vegetables, legumes (dried beans and peas), grains, seeds and nuts.

The Lacto-vegetarian diet includes plant foods plus cheese and other dairy products. The Ovo-lacto-vegetarian diet also includes eggs. Semi-vegetarians don't eat red meat but include chicken and fish with plant foods, dairy products and eggs

How the POINTS system works Every food has a POINTS value, which is calculated based on a food’s kilojoules and saturated fat. POINTS values help you keep track of what you eat, so that you stay within a daily POINTS Target that’s personalised for you, based on your height, weight and other factors, such as gender. Along with your daily POINTS Target, you also get a “Weekly Allowance” to use for a special occasion like a night on the town, so you can still indulge sometimes, without going off track.

The diet is based on a study published in the American Journal of Clinical Nutrition which compared the weight loss between two groups… ...both receiving the same amount of daily calorie intake, but one on a high carbohydrate diet and the other on a high protein diet. The study showed that both groups lost weight, but those on the high protein diet lost more and felt better. This group lost more weight on the high protein diet, but most importantly, they lost twice the amount of body fat, and markers indicating risk of heart disease and diabetes improved significantly.

A long term study done after a year on the high protein diet showed that dieters had managed to maintain weight loss, and on average were 3 kilograms lighter than their counterparts on the high carbohydrate diet. CSIRO has spent the past few years exploring the healthiest and most successful ways to lose weight. In recent studies they demonstrated the benefits of an eating plan that provides more protein and less refined carbohydrates.

CSIRO has ALSO conducted several of the largest studies showing that higher protein dietary patterns for weight management have metabolic advantages over high carbohydrate patterns in overweight people. The results clearly showed health benefits and significant weight loss from a diet higher in proteins and low in fats and the Total Wellbeing Diet was born.

There are blood tests available that will test your allergenic response to foods. These are more accurate in determining suitable food types specific to the individual needs, as apposed to a generalized classification as seen in blood typing. This is the second most common blood type found. Again according to Dr D'Adamo, digestive system is apparently very good at remembering that our ancestors had settled, farming lifestyles, which included eating lots of grains and vegetables but little meat.

Discovered in 1965, aspartame is a low-calorie sweetener with a sugar-like taste but is approximately 200 times sweeter than sucrose, Aspartame is unique among low-calorie sweeteners in that it is completely broken down by the body to its components – the amino acids, aspartic acid and phenylalanine, and a small amount of methanol (Methyl ester), and Currently, aspartame is found in more than 6,000 products and is consumed by over 200 million people around the world.

Tastes Sweet and Clean - Studies conducted show that aspartame's taste is very similar to the taste of sugar, Enhances and Extends Flavors - Aspartame has the ability to intensify and extend fruit flavors, Does Not Promote Tooth Decay Is Helpful for Individuals with Diabetes - allows them to satisfy their taste for sweets without affecting blood sugar.

…is a non-caloric sweetener, discovered in 1967, acesulfame potassium (also known as acesulfame K) is approximately 200 times sweeter than sucrose. It has a clean, sweet taste that does not linger or leave an aftertaste. It is not metabolized by the body and is excreted unchanged.

Helps Reduce Calories— Since acesulfame K is not metabolized, it contributes no calories, Remains Stable Under High Temperatures— The sweet taste of acesulfame K remains unchanged during baking, Tastes Sweet and Clean— Acesulfame K generally does not exhibit any off-taste in foods and soft drinks, Does Not Promote Tooth Decay, and Useful in Diabetic Diets— Studies have shown that acesulfame K has no effect on serum glucose, cholesterol, or triglycerides.

Discovered in 1976, Sucralose is the only non-caloric sweetener made from sugar through a multi-step patented manufacturing process, This change produces a sweetener that has no calories, yet is 600 times sweeter than sucrose. It tastes like sugar and does not leave an unpleasant aftertaste, Sucralose is not utilized for energy in the body because it is not broken down like sucrose, It passes rapidly through the body virtually unchanged
Cyclamate is a non-caloric sweetener discovered in 1937. It has been used widely in low-calorie foods and beverages. Most people do not metabolise cyclamate.

Saccharin is 300 times sweeter than sugar, which means only a little is needed for sweetening. However, like most artificial sweeteners, it has an unpleasant, bitter aftertaste. It is stable when heated. It also passes through the body without having any impact on the blood sugar levels.
